description: Data summaries and descriptive statistics; introduction to a statistical computer package; Probability: distributions, expectation, variance, covariance, portfolios, central limit theorem; statistical inference of univariate data; Statistical inference for bivariate data: inference for intrinsically linear simple regression models. This course will have a business focus, but is not inappropriate for students in the college.
name: INTRO BUSINESS STAT

values.comments:
Statistics 101 develops ideas for helping to make decisions based on data. Some of the following material is covered: data displays and summary statistics for quantitative and qualitative variables, correlation and simple regression for pairs of variables, probability as a measure of uncertainty and as limiting relative frequency, the law of large numbers, the normal distribution and the central limit theorem, statistical inference based on standard errors, confidence intervals, and statistical hypothesis tests. The course does not dwell on the details of computation—its main focus is on understanding a few deep concepts and interpreting data and statistical results.

Overall, students had fairly positive impressions of the class. A number commented on the “boring” and “bland” material but a number said that the lectures were “rather engaging” all the same. One student commented that the concepts learned “definitely seem useful later on” and another described the course as his or her “favorite class this semester.”

Students had very positive things to say about Professor Rakhlin, describing him as “awesome,” “amazing,” and in a couple of cases, a “favorite” professor. Specifically, students appreciated his enthusiasm, his "jokes,” and his ability to “keep the classroom entertaining.” A couple of students said that he “does a wonderful job of explaining the concepts to us."

Students commented that there was a moderate amount of work as the “only homework is weekly problem sets, which can take several hours to complete.” One student noted that “the textbook reading is not necessary to keep up with the class, but is helpful with homework.” Overall, this student described the course as “not terribly difficult or time consuming” but also “not easy.” Statistics 101 is one of the business fundamentals classes required for Wharton students. Math 104 is required as a prerequisite.
